cluster_relations.rel_desc: The World Cup creates a sense of belonging among fans.
The Olympics create a sense of belonging among fans.
The World Cup fosters pride among fans.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Trigger: achievements of teams and athletes

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Olympics foster pride among fans.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Trigger: achievements of teams and athletes

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The sense of belonging is an emotional state experienced by fans.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: in the context of major sports events

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Pride is an emotional state experienced by fans.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: in connection with achievements of teams and athletes

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an event or situation causally brings about or strengthens a particular emotional state in a target group.
args.justification: All four relations describe major sporting events (World Cup, Olympics) causally generating specific emotional states (sense of belonging, pride) among fans; these share the same direction and semantics of an event evoking an emotional state.
These relations all describe the emotional impact of large-scale sports events on audiences, forming a natural class of event-to-emotion causal links.
The semantics is explicitly causal: the events create or foster the emotional states, matching a causality-oriented group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an emotional or mental state is subjectively experienced by a particular group of people or agents.
args.justification: Both relations link an emotional state (sense of belonging, pride) to the group that subjectively experiences it (fans) with identical direction and meaning; the existing hint 'experienced_by' already matches this predicate well.
These relations systematically capture which agents experience which emotional states in a sports context, forming a coherent emotional-experience class distinct from event-to-emotion impact.
The focus is on the role of agents (fans) as experiencers of emotional states, fitting a broad agency/participant-oriented grouping better than pure causality.
